29.30.text: Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up

32.09.text:
It's a snow and fog bound Inverness-shire
but the grouse are still flying like rockets.

37.79.text:
We have Skinners gundog training tips, we
have News Stump and Hunting YouTube.

41.88.text:
First, PIGEONS. We have found some! But is
it a case of 'Water, water, every where,:

66.74.text:
Here's a sight for sore eyes - pigeons - lots
of pigeons - but it's a case of so near and

74.65.text:
Bit like everywhere else in the country, no
one has had any pigeons. They have migrated

76.40.text:
through and I am lucky enough that I have
got a load that stocked up on acorns here.

81.13.text:
So what we are doing at the moment is letting
them come out. They rest here for a bit then

82.10.text:
they spread out and we are hopefully going
to shoot a few. Same old problem, there are

91.94.text:
a lot of acorns about down here so when you
might get a shot they get up and just go over

100.82.text: the hedge. We will find out in a minute.

103.21.text:
Crow has been watching them fly over the farm
every morning between 7.30 and 8 o'clock for

107.75.text:
the past week. With the whiff of foreign pigeon
in the air, Andy has invited the man who's

112.44.text:
responsible for teaching both Andy and certain
Mr Digweed everything they know about pigeon

117.39.text:
shooting, game dealer Adrian Netchie and his
wife Ann.

120.49.text:
I always like to put the guests in the hot
spot. So they are going down, there is a pond

126.14.text:
down where me and George shot the crows, well
George shot the crows recently.

131.08.text:
They are semi retired and were looking forward
to whiling away their new found freedom shooting

134.81.text:
their days away, but it just hasn't happened.
There is hope today.

140.26.text:
The pigeons are so scarce there are hardly
enough to stick on the whirly.

143.81.text:
It has already started today. Adrian is fighting
over who is going to get what for the whirly.

146.84.text:
I have managed to get two out of him. Yes,
so he has got 20 decoys. He has only given

152.50.text: me two, but that is the way it goes.

155.70.text:
While Andy's cousin Gary helps Adrian and
Ann set-up on one part of the farm. Andy takes

160.79.text:
us across to the other side where he's spotted
them dropping. This part of the farm is unfortunately

166.44.text:
out of bounds as there is a pheasant shoot
here at the weekend.

169.86.text:
These have just moved in. Hopefully they will
stay. They have got enough grub here to keep

179.42.text:
them going. I don't want them out here obviously
because they are on the rape. They are only

187.71.text:
here having a peck on the rape, so as I say
they are just working their way out under

189.81.text:
the oak trees because it is just a carpet
of acorns.

203.69.text:
Crow reckons there's about 5,000 - but that's
half of what it was yesterday.

208.98.text:
Despite Crow's clapping they don't seem to
want to shift from here. We just hope the

212.43.text:
birds start splintering off into smaller groups
that like the look of The A1 decoys. They

217.38.text:
are more useful than ever this year when real
pigeons are like gold dust. How else do we

223.77.text:
We have got two for the whirly which Adrian
has brought up we can stick a few plastic

228.37.text:
out just to attract their attention really
so we can shoot a few. As soon as we shoot

231.59.text:
them we will just bring these plastics in
any way. These are half flock coated A1. These

238.13.text:
are from A1 so we will keep these out here
for a bit.

243.63.text:
With Adrian and Ann set up, Crow needs to
get a shift on. Here is some high speed hide

257.66.text:
Unfortunately it's a case of hurry up and
wait - the birds are about but they're so

261.19.text:
high and hardly worth lifting the Lincoln
skywards. There are one or two chances for

270.97.text:
the Gamebore Clear Pigeons to hit home. We're
just wondering what might have been if we'd

274.72.text: been able to shoot near the shoot. Oh well.

293.44.text:
Word on the street is that it will all switch
on at 1100.

296.55.text:
I have just been talking to Adrian and we
think they will switch on between eleven and

304.19.text:
two which is their best feeding time. So that
is what we are hoping. They are being a bit

308.74.text:
wary at the moment. There isn't a lot of wind.
They are going a bit wide, a bit wide of us.

315.65.text:
About another five minutes before it is eleven
o'clock . So hopefully after eleven o'clock

319.39.text:
it is going to start, but don't hold it to
me David.

321.96.text:
Oh dear - even Ruby, usually the busiest dog
in the South of England. starts thinking it's

331.65.text:
We do get some shots - but not enough to get
excited - Crow even resorts to showing Gary

336.31.text:
last week's episode of Fieldsports Britain...
desperate measures!

342.41.text:
On the other side of the fields Adrian and
Ann are getting some sport but it's tough

347.16.text:
going - 40 birds to add to Crow's 8 - exceptional
given the circumstances and probably worth

353.41.text: a fiver each - may be not.

356.37.text:
So there you have it - essential kit for a
pigeon hide - gun, shells, dog and smartphone

361.00.text:
to Fieldsports Channel when it all goes quiet.
Plus we give you an excellent excuse when

366.08.text:
u exit the loo looking flustered with an iPad
- other fablets and tablets are available.

371.25.text:
Right, someone else who's had the chip implant,
it's David on the Fieldsports Channel News

385.46.text:
With wildlife and shooting issues hitting
the headlines in the UK, the Fieldsports Channel

389.61.text:
team have been out making the case for countrysports
in the media.

392.99.text:
Roy Lupton has been on BBC radio explaining
that walkers are not being shot at when shot

398.31.text:
drops near them, despite one women's fears
someone will be killed. Roy was also allowed

403.64.text:
to air his views on walkers actually sticking
to footpaths in the first place.

407.60.text:
From a wildlife perspective as well with these
people popping up, appearing where they shouldn't

413.30.text:
be with dogs not under control it is causing
a lot of problems to wildlife.

418.46.text:
Even Charlie has been in on the act, talking
to BBC News about the badger cull.

422.76.text:
Protestors did everything right by the media
and there was all that nonsense about hearing

427.20.text:
badgers screaming in the middle of the night,
what? But they did it right. That sort of

431.83.text:
thing made the press and whenever the press
or broadcast ask the national Farmers Union

436.47.text:
for a comment they say would you like to meet
a farmer who has lost his herd to TB which

439.96.text:
is all very worthy but it doesn't tell the
story.

442.71.text:
Roy and Charlie doing their bit there, or
better known in the press, marksmen.

447.97.text:
Now frozen yogurt is currently quite trendy,
but we didn't know that word had spread to

452.96.text:
wildlife. A deer pushed through the swinging
door of a 'Peachwave' shop in New Jersey,

458.07.text:
USA, last month and had an exciting romp,
doing $5,000 in damage to the shop as it freaked

464.08.text:
out because its hooves could not get any traction
on the shiny floor. The owner's son set the

469.10.text:
CCTV footage to you guessed it "Benny Hill"
and posted it on YouTube.

472.89.text:
A horse race in June featuring Shires galloping
at Lingfield Park Racecourse has won a national

480.96.text:
award. The Showerking Flying Feathers Maiden
Stakes was the first Shire horse race to be

485.18.text:
staged in Britain on a racecourse and was
held to raise money for the Countryside Alliance

489.39.text:
Foundation. The 400m race won its award at
the annual Racecourse Association Awards.

495.27.text:
All the horses were provided by Hurst Green
Shires, and the race was won by Joey, who

500.04.text: was ridden to victory by Mark Grant.

504.09.text:
Anyone caught out by gun licensing laws can
take heart from a police raid at a farm in

509.92.text:
Queensland, Australia. The farmer and his
two sons had more than 300 guns and 4.2 tons

515.92.text:
of ammunition. The men were licensed to have
just 71 weapons. Most of the stockpile was

521.91.text:
illegal, said Detective Superintendent Jon
Wacker of the Queensland Police.

528.44.text:
Now Americans are bumping into so many large
animals, they are changing their hunting laws.

533.82.text:
Faced with an outbreak of lyme disease and
rising deer-related car accidents, a North

538.33.text:
Carolina city has authorised bow hunting within
the city limits, as has a city in Illinois,

541.79.text:
provided that it occurs in green spaces such
as golf courses, parks and cemeteries. Even

542.20.text:
in the heart of Silicon Valley, California,
authorities have voted to allow hunting wild

542.27.text:
pigs. The problem is so acute, it has made
the front cover of Time magazine.

547.54.text:
New Zealand seafishers face an unusual problem
This angler is happily reeling in an Australian

553.08.text:
salmon when gannets go for it. Fast thinking
and fast playing saves the day and the sea

561.16.text:
And finally, it had to happen. A group of
American hunters have posted their response

565.58.text: to the YouTube hit 'What Does the Fox Say?'

573.54.text:
What does the buck say?' is filmed on more
of a budget than the original.

578.90.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Channel
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

591.17.text:
Thank you David. Next let's see what you lot
have been up to this week, it's 'Hallo Charlie!'.

599.78.text:
Here is what the world has been up to this
week.

602.25.text:
Hallo Charlie here we are in Norfolk waiting
for some pheasants.

608.68.text:
Hallo Charlie this is Declan Fodery. Hallo
Charlie we have just had a busy weekend . We

616.01.text:
have three stags here we need to take care
of before we head out again this evening.

618.94.text:
Hallo Charlie. Mr Fermanaghman here on an
over cast Northern Ireland out doing a bit

624.39.text:
of rough shooting this afternoon. And hopefully
we will get a rabbit or two for the pot. See

631.64.text:
Hallo Charlie. Here we are doing a bit of
ferreting in the beautiful winter sunshine

636.88.text:
in the Suffolk countryside. My name is Shaun,
my name is Torgid, my name is Sooty, I am

643.10.text:
Romford and I am Mr Taylor. Thank you Charlie
and good night.

647.55.text:
Hallo Charlie my name is Richard Hiley. We
are at the boar shooting ground and we are

654.04.text:
Send us your own Hallo Charlie. Film yourself
on your mobile phone with just a sentence

658.05.text:
saying Hallo Charlie, who you are and what
you are up to. Then share it or email it via

661.99.text:
Youtube, Facebook, Dropbox or Yousendit, Younameit
to Charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

667.19.text:
Keep 'em coming, especially if you're feeling
festive, why not send us some themed 'Hallo

673.30.text:
Now it is time for our top gundog training
tips with the experts from Skinners Petfoods.

687.14.text:
After sit and stay obedience, the next step
is making sure the dog is steady to heel.

692.53.text:
What is more frustrating than a dog which
keeps walking ahead. Top gundog trainer, Tom

696.97.text: West, explains how he goes about it.

699.43.text:
Today we stand with a young dog. The way it
all starts is on the lead. The only contact

704.01.text:
you have got to start with is the lead. Once
you have got the dog and you are comfortable

709.72.text:
the dog is not pulling you, the dog is listening
to you and keen on following with you then

714.92.text:
your next stage is to drop the lead. I usually
drop it over the dog's back so that it is

719.93.text:
not dragging on the floor and then the only
contact you are keeping the dog at your heel

725.39.text:
is with your voice. When you are confident
with that you take the dog off the lead and

731.15.text:
the dog should be staying with you if it is
not, back to square one. Put it back on the

735.92.text:
lead and you reinforce it. Don't forget the
praise. We all like a bit of praise. It is

742.75.text:
very important. When the dog is doing what
it is told, you praise it. When it is not,

747.91.text:
your voice is firmer. It is all in the tone
of the voice and your body language.

752.17.text:
Tom runs West Halagun Dogs near Perth in Scotland.
Visit www.westhalagundogs.co.uk This series

758.80.text:
on gundog training tips is brought to you
by Skinners Petfood. Maker of the Field and

762.65.text: Trial range of gundog feeds. Visit www.skinnerspetfoods.co.uk

768.99.text:
Next up the grouse shooting season is over
in some parts of the country, but north of

772.60.text: the border they are still enjoying it.

779.99.text:
It's a grey day as a team of mixed English
and Scottish guns drive up the sides of the

784.54.text:
Monadhliath Hills. They have grouse on their
minds today, and the swirling, skirling mist

789.33.text: may mean just that. Bang - missed.

800.77.text:
Just because it's a bit foggy doesn't stop
these incredible game birds hitting 65mph

805.99.text:
as they come rattling out of the gloom and
pass the butts.

810.50.text:
We did think we would have to cancel, but
we are just getting by. It's a young team

826.22.text:
so have to watch for the dangers for them
as well. It is going well considering.

831.59.text:
Now we have conducted plenty of ammunition
tests. And there's lots of shotgun shell theory

836.52.text:
out there on the internet. But when it comes
down to it, and this is 'it', you have to

843.00.text:
Hull is just sterling game. Doesn't hurt the
shoulder too much. They are good.

850.65.text:
Hull Cartridge recommends Imperial Game for
these red Scots devils - They've sent a few

855.90.text:
cases for these seasoned guns to try, but
some have their own ideas.

860.77.text:
On occasional gaps in the mist, you can see
just what spectacular shooting this estate

865.76.text:
provides. And now and again you get more of
a glimpse before the grouse have been and

870.06.text:
gone. One shooter witnessing some amazing
grouse fly-bys is a Hull High Pheasant fan.

876.81.text:
This last year I have been using the number
six, thirty grammes, number sixes Hull produce.

883.55.text:
I just find them really consistent I guess.
For the higher birds on the game drives I

892.67.text:
might choose to use a number five, thirty
two grammes. I think it is consistency for

900.42.text:
me. That is why I choose to use them and they
are affordable.

909.46.text:
Half way through the day, there's a break
for a sandwich and pie lunch in Iain's well-appointed

913.47.text:
moorland hut, complete with roaring woodburner.
Then it's back into the vehicles and we're

926.46.text:
The grouse have been flying well offering
some really challenging sport. So do they

932.32.text:
They are cause though there is snow on the
ground, actually the temperature today is

936.34.text:
milder so they are not nearly as packed as
they normally would be when there is snow

940.45.text:
on the ground. So they actually worked quite
well for us today in fairness.

946.52.text:
We need to get a move with the last drive
the sun is definitely moving from thin and

954.18.text:
Finally we find someone using Imperial Game
- but he beats us to it and had already stocked

959.43.text: up before the offer of the freebies.

961.06.text:
I would recommend them. I might even choose
them the next time I stock up.

965.14.text:
We really need to get a move on with the last
drive before it is grouse by candlelight.

969.50.text:
I am very impressed with you lot. Firstly
for shooting in fog and now shooting in darkness.

978.32.text: We do it all the time. We practice it.

980.45.text:
You are just the keenest team of guns out
there.

985.70.text:
We practice it we are from south London you
know. We have to keep our wits about us.

991.28.text:
Our point man in the Highlands, Lachie Smith,
is the agent who organised today. What does

997.62.text:
The great thing with grouse at this time of
the year Charlie is that there are very, very

1001.22.text:
few wounded. It is either a clean kill or
a clean miss. Usually miss them at about 20

1006.50.text:
metres and it is quite refreshing because
they are really difficult targets. They are

1010.09.text:
a lot of fun and you have your day's sport.
Nobody knows what the bag is going to be at

1014.23.text:
the very end. And actually the question you
just ask, what is the bag every body is going

1018.05.text:
to ask it because nobody knows, nobody is
really bothered. It is just fun being there.

1021.44.text: Being on the hill, in the highlands is priceless.

1024.66.text:
Well, that's one happy gun. If you would like
to go driven grouse-shooting, contact Lachie

1029.29.text:
by email ls@highlandsporting.com. And if you
would like to learn more about Hull's range

1039.53.text:
Well thank you Hull Cartridge for making that
film possible. From the Scottish moors to

1050.06.text:
This week Jason Bruce's Headhunter Chronicles
series takes us on a hunting adventure in

1054.79.text:
Iran. Once he's managed to get through the
red -tape he has to negotiate some incredible

1059.68.text:
terrain to get within range of persian Ibex,
red sheep and mouflon. Back in vision - If

1067.27.text:
you haven't seen any of the series so far,
this one is well worth a look. Now inspired

1073.11.text:
by Jason's escapades let's look at overseas
hunting, and shooting and fishing, on Hunting

1085.41.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1089.80.text:
With Christmas around the corner who's for
a romantic romp through a lovely English shooting

1094.27.text:
day, thanks to best London gunmaker James
Purdey & Sons? This film comes wrapped in

1099.28.text:
a piecrust of delicious sentimentality with
a dreamy topping of stunning production values

1104.14.text:
- practically has a sprig of holly on top.
Well done James Purdey.

1108.01.text:
At the other end of British shooting, Chris
and Dan at Nelson Field Target Club in Caerphilly,

1112.68.text:
home, they point out, of the cheese, recommends
AirGunHuntersTV, who reviews BSAs and Weihrauch

1117.68.text:
and Crosmans and even the Jack Pyke hand warming
kit. In this test it's the BSA Ultra Tactical

1124.22.text:
Now lots of people across Europe are wildfowling
at the moment and 'Duck hunting in Sweden'

1128.52.text:
is all this film gives by way of description.
What it shows is some amazing shooting and

1132.85.text:
some fairly intelligent editing considering
this is a GoPro show.

1136.29.text:
Staying in Scandinavia - well it will be when
they get independence from the English yoke

1139.30.text:
- let's go to Scotland and the River Clyde
where FromField2StreamTV is offering grayling

1143.74.text:
fishing with characteristic sense of humour.
Once a river polluted by heavy industry the

1147.91.text:
Clyde has now become a fisherman's dream with
good runs of salmon and large numbers of good-quality

1153.63.text:
On the other side of the world, the sun is
out in Australia so hard it is worth fishing

1156.72.text:
at dawn, which is what DizzyFishUK is doing,
travelliung more than 10,000 miles to go kayak

1161.86.text:
fishing for red snapper. They are lure fishing
with light tackle off Mornington in Victoria.

1166.30.text:
Now, liven up your back garden with this idea
from South Africa. Exploding targets for airgunners

1171.05.text: and how to make them cheaply.

1173.10.text:
More southern hemisphere madness: we have
covered the San People of Southern Africa

1176.43.text:
doing it with antelope, now wild man Andrew
Ucles is in the outback of Australia on a

1180.32.text:
mission to locate and run down a feral goat.
Why are there not more people like him?

1185.13.text:
Finally, want to know what it's like in the
New Russia? Viewer Aleks F recommends hunting

1188.82.text:
hares in Bessarabia with Artsiz and Bolhrad.
Yes it's in Russian but hunting is an international

1193.80.text:
language, spoken by a lot more people than
anti-hunting. The channel is called ??????????? ?????? ? ????????- literally

1200.56.text:
'Adventure fisherman and hunter' - that's
the Google translation and I'm sticking to

1203.77.text:
it - and it comes with plenty of ho-ho-ho
music.

1207.15.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1210.01.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube or email me the link

1216.06.text:
Well we are back next week and if you are
watching this on Youtube please don't hesitate

1219.57.text:
to hit the subscribe button which is somewhere
on the outside of the screen, I might put

1223.33.text:
it on the screen. Or go to our webpage www.fieldsportschannel.tv
where you can click to like us on Facebook,

1228.50.text:
follow us on Twitter or any number of social
media or you can scroll down to the bottom

1233.53.text:
and pop your email address into the constant
contact form and we will be in touch with

1237.16.text:
you by email about our programme which is
out at 7pm every Wednesday UK time. This has

1242.83.text:
been Fieldsports Britain. Good bye, good hunting,
good shooting and good fishing.
